description.narrative: New/additional funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 Sida supports UNFPA's country program in Sudan through a non-earmarked programme support with SEK 45 million in period between 2017-2020. The total budget of the country programme 2018-2021 is approximately USD 40 million. The country programme is iplemented within three strategic outcome areas: sexual and reproductive health, gender equality and women's empowerment and population dynamics. The overall goal of the UNFPA country programme for Sudan is to reduce maternal deaths and disabilities through an integrated approach to sexual and eproductive health, family planning and prevention and response to gender-based violence. The programme seeks to strengthen capacities of health ministries and civil society partners at federal and priority state level. The objectives of the programme include to ensure access to high-quality sexual and reproductive services, family planning services, and preventing and responding to gender-based violence, while also increasing national capacities for data production and analysis. UNFPA's country programme includes both development and humanitarian interventions. Humanitarian needs in this context are often protracted and require a flexible approach that supports both development and humanitarian assistance.

Nya medel/medeltillägg för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Sida stödjer UNFPAs landprogram i Sudan genom ett icke-öronmärkt programstöd på 45 miljoner SEK under perioden 2017-2020. Landprogrammets totala budget är ca 40 miljoner USD under en programperiod på fyra år. Landprogrammet implementeras inom tre strategiska områden: sexuell och reproduktiv hälsa, jämställdhet och kvinnors egenmakt samt befolkningsutveckling. Det övergripande målet för UNFPAs landprogram i Sudan är att minska mödradödlighet genom ett integrerat stöd till sexuell och reproduktiv hälsa, familjeplanering och genom att förebygga och hantera könsbaserat våld. Programmet syftar till att stärka den institutionella kapaciteten hos hälsovårdsministerier och det civila samhället inom prioriterade stater i Sudan. UNFPAs landprogram omfattar både utvecklingsinsatser och humanitärt stöd. Humanitära behov i denna kontext är ofta långvariga och kräver ett flexibelt tillvägagångssätt som stödjer både utvecklingsinsatser och humanitärt arbete.

The overall goal of UNFPA's country program in Sudan is to reduce maternal deaths and disabilities through an integrated approach to sexual and reproductive health, family planning and prevention and response to gender-based violence (GBV). The key objectives include: • Strengthened capacities of health ministries and civil society partners at federal and state level to ensure access to high-quality SRH services, including in humanitarian settings. • Strengthened capacities of health ministries and civil society partners at federal and state level for better access to high-quality family planning services, including in humanitarian settings. • Strengthened capacity of government and civil society institutions to prevent and respond to GBV, with a special focus on women and young girls, including in humanitarian settings. UNFPA has requested an amendment to the current agreement, which entails a cost extension by 2 years and an additional 30 million USD. UNFPA states that the purpose of the amendment is twofold: 1. Support the continuity of care, specifically lifesaving emergency obstetric care, as well as improving referral to care - these efforts are currently hampered by Covid 19. This is to be done by supporting basic and comprehensive EmONC facilities with PPE and IPC supplies, as well as investing in active referral of obstetric complications. The interventions will also include procurement and distribution of modified dignity kits for vulnerable women and girls as entry point for GBV awareness and promotion of GBV services to ensure continuity of services and protection. (2 million USD). 2. Support the population census, which will be combined with the agricultural census for the first time. This is among the most urgent requirements for the transitional government of Sudan, which will need early, careful, and joint planning and preparations. Full transformation from traditional paper-intensive to highly digitized paper-less census requires sufficient funding and investments in building national capacities in the next two years, to ensure a fair, accurate, and a successful census (1 million USD).

tag.narrative: 3.7 - By 2030, ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health-care services, including for family planning, information and education, and the integration of reproductive health into national strategies and programmes.

3.7 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att alla har tillgång till sexuell och reproduktiv hälsovård, inklusive familjeplanering, information och utbildning, och att reproduktiv hälsa integreras i nationella strategier och program.
5.1 - Avskaffa alla former av diskriminering av alla kvinnor och flickor överallt
5.1 - End all forms of discrimination against all women and girls everywhere.
5.3 - Avskaffa alla skadliga sedvänjor, såsom barnäktenskap, tidiga äktenskap och tvångsäktenskap samt kvinnlig könsstympning.
5.3 - Eliminate all harmful practices, such as child, early and forced marriage and female genital mutilation.

title.narrative: Beslut om ändring av insats UNFPA Sudan
Standard Contribution Agreement Sweden - UNFPA Sudan

description.narrative: After submitting an updated work plan, with redistribution of activities, UNFPA received extra funding from Sida to counter the effects of the covid-19 pandemic and a forthcoming census in Sudan. As a result, UNFPA Sudan addressed the needs of the Covid-19 response through: Ensuring continuity of sexual and reproductive health services; addressing gender-based violence and mitigation measures; protection of the health workforce and risk- communication and outreach strategies. In 2020, UNFPA achieved 73% of its work plan in real terms, which was lower than last year. The reason was mainly COVID -19 and the increasingly difficult economic situation in the country making everything more expensive. In 2020 UNFPA was most successful in family planning, reaching 101%. A national FP strategy and demand-driven investments have led to an increase in the use of contraceptives among both old and new users (albeit from a low level). According to the Impact Model 192 cases of maternal mortality, 109,000 unwanted pregnancies and 42,950 unsafe abortions were prevented in 2020. GBV had a fulfilment rate of 87% and SRH 77%. UNFPA continued its “Last Mile Assurance” and has also developed a spot check plan for 2021. The “Last Miles Assurance” is part of the global plan for sustaining family planning and maternal health supplies. UNFPA also contributed to changes at the system level. A draft law for preventing child marriage has been developed with the support of UNFPA and other partners. The draft is currently (July 21) a part of the review of the family status law. It will, within short, be presented for the ministry of Justice. In 2020, the first national fistula strategy was prepared and adopted. Education for midwives also improved through the merging of schools and a new curriculum. In 2021 the curriculum for Midwife Diploma was sent for final endorsement by the Ministry of Higher Education. Master training of trainers started in the first quarter of 2021. The Voices from Sudan was finalised in July 2021. It is the first nationwide qualitative study on GBV and thereby fills a critical gap in data collection. The contribution for the upcoming Census has been used for the employment of a Chief Technical Advisor, procurement of the first set of IT equipment for methodology pre-tests and field mission assessment of the Census State Offices.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
